title: Back to School With Food Allergies

content: Is it time for school already? The back-to-school season is exciting for some but can be anxiety-inducing for others. The prospect of new teachers, activities, or even new schools should be fun, but for families managing food allergies, it means an added layer of planning. It involves setting up and taking the proper precautions regarding your kids' food allergies. While navigating food allergies can be challenging, with preparation and communication, it does not have to be overwhelming.
Here are a few things I do to prepare for each school year:

The start of a new school year is a good opportunity to renew prescriptions and review allergy plans. We use this time to schedule appointments with the primary doctor and the allergist. Fortunately, my daughters have outgrown a few allergies, so their allergy action plans have been changing yearly for the past few years.
2. Update medical information at the school

Ensure that new or updated allergy plans are on file with the school, and bring updated epinephrine auto-injectors and/or antihistamines. Remember to confirm medical updates on the school’s electronic platform.

Ensure that new or updated allergy plans are on file with the school, and bring updated epinephrine auto-injectors and/or antihistamines. Remember to confirm medical updates on the school’s electronic platform.

sections.heading: 3. Meet with school staff
content: I arrange meetings with the principal, nurse, homeroom teachers, and the cafeteria manager to discuss my daughters’ food allergies. As we are now in our fourth year at the same school, I prefer to have these discussions via formal emails for written documentation and then have quick in-person follow-ups for any verbal clarifications that may be needed. Even though my daughters bring their own packed lunches and snacks, it is important that the cafeteria staff be aware of their allergies in case the girls forget their food or any unforeseen circumstances arise. This is a good time to review updated allergy action plans and the storage location for medications such as epinephrine auto-injectors, and to clarify any policies regarding food in the classroom, including parties and in-class projects involving food. It is crucial for my girls to be included in class projects, so I kindly request the teachers to contact me for additional safe treats for the classroom. This allows me to provide alternatives for my daughters so they can participate alongside their classmates.

sections.heading: 4. Purchase safe food for lunch and snacks
content: Adding to the already extensive school supply list are safe foods for school. Bringing food from home helps ensure the girls' safety regarding food allergies. I typically don't send new foods to school as I like to try them at home first. I also include the girls in the process of choosing lunches and snacks. I used to get excited to find allergy-friendly foods, only to discover that the kids may not like them. Now, I let them choose their favorite foods for school while adding a few additional safe options of my own. This gives them more control over their food choices.

To prevent mix-ups, we label all items sent to school, such as lunch boxes, water bottles, school supplies, jackets, and scarves. This practice is important for all students, particularly those with food allergies, as we cannot guarantee the absence of allergens in the belongings of other kids.

sections.heading: 6. Practice self-advocacy
content: Self-advocacy is a crucial skill in my household. We have been practicing since the original food allergy diagnosis. We often practice scenarios through role playing, such as what to do if another student or adult offers food. It's important to differentiate between peers and adults as they can respond differently. We also discuss recognizing allergic reaction symptoms and how to communicate them. Teaching my daughters to manage their allergies and speak up if they feel something is wrong is essential because we can't be with them all the time. I also emphasize the importance of not sharing food with others. Practicing these situations helps my daughters feel confident and prepared for school.

When your child with food allergies goes back to school, it requires extra planning and precautions. However, it doesn't have to be a source of constant worry. By being proactive, communicating openly, and educating those around you, you can help ensure that your child has a safe, healthy, and enjoyable school year. Remember, you're not alone in this journey – there's a whole community of parents, teachers, and health care professionals ready to support you. So take a deep breath, trust in your preparations, and let your child thrive in the new school year!
